issue.title: support fixed joint types in Gazebo

content.raw:
Just because the issue was updated: sometimes we have problems (the model simulation does not start at all) with fixed joints implemented with revolute joints with zero limits  using Simbody or DART. The exact same models in which this fixed joints are lumped run without problem. 

Considering how minimal coordinates simulations engines work, properly implementing fixed joints using [SimTK::MobilizedBody::Weld](https://simtk.org/api_docs/simbody/latest/classSimTK_1_1MobilizedBody_1_1Weld.html) or [dart::dynamics::WeldJoint](http://dartsim.github.io/dart/d8/da2/classdart_1_1dynamics_1_1WeldJoint.html) should solve this kind of problems.
content.html:
Just because the issue was updated: sometimes we have problems (the model simulation does not start at all) with fixed joints implemented with revolute joints with zero limits using Simbody or DART. The exact same models in which this fixed joints are lumped run without problem.

Considering how minimal coordinates simulations engines work, properly implementing fixed joints using SimTK::MobilizedBody::Weld or dart::dynamics::WeldJoint should solve this kind of problems.

content.raw:
I am trying to solve this issue for increase the stability of 6 axis Force/Torque sensors simulation on reduced coordinates engines (DART & Simbody).
 Once there is something ready for review, do you prefer it to be split in multiple PRs (one for basic fixed joint infrastructure and then one for each physics engine) or do you prefer a single PR?
content.html: I am trying to solve this issue for increase the stability of 6 axis Force/Torque sensors simulation on reduced coordinates engines (DART & Simbody). Once there is something ready for review, do you prefer it to be split in multiple PRs (one for basic fixed joint infrastructure and then one for each physics engine) or do you prefer a single PR?

issue.title: support fixed joint types in Gazebo

content.raw: Multiple PRs are usually better as they are easy to review.
content.html: Multiple PRs are usually better as they are easy to review.

issue.title: support fixed joint types in Gazebo

content.raw:
I have implemented a first prototype of fixed joint, currently only targeting simbody. 

## SDF modifications ##
Fortunately the modification necessary to SDF are minimal . They boil down to make the `axis` child of `joint` element not required. However it is already possible to use the fixed joint element with the existing SDF version, as long as you ad a dummy `<axis>` element. 
The necessary modifications are committed in https://bitbucket.org/traversaro/sdformat/branch/gazebo_issue_1278 . 

## Gazebo modifications ##

The first implementation is available in https://bitbucket.org/traversaro/gazebo-fork/branch/issue_1278 . 
The only available test is really a basic test, but I guess the best strategy is to use some existing test with some new model that includes some fixed joint in the structure. Any suggestions?
content.html:
I have implemented a first prototype of fixed joint, currently only targeting simbody.

SDF modifications

Fortunately the modification necessary to SDF are minimal . They boil down to make the axis child of joint element not required. However it is already possible to use the fixed joint element with the existing SDF version, as long as you ad a dummy <axis> element. The necessary modifications are committed in https://bitbucket.org/traversaro/sdformat/branch/gazebo_issue_1278 .

Gazebo modifications

The first implementation is available in https://bitbucket.org/traversaro/gazebo-fork/branch/issue_1278 . The only available test is really a basic test, but I guess the best strategy is to use some existing test with some new model that includes some fixed joint in the structure. Any suggestions?

issue.title: support fixed joint types in Gazebo

content.raw:
I had some time to spent on this and I decided to go on and implement the fixed joint support also on the other physics engine, because the amount of physics engine-specific code necessary was surprisingly limited.

## Simbody
Simbody implementation seems to work fine, using `SimTK::MobilizedBody::Weld`.

## DART
DART was implemented using `dart::dynamics::WeldJoint` and it seems to work fine.

## ODE 
ODE was implemented using the `Fixed` joint. If for any reason this fixed joint is more unstable than the Hinge joint with 0 max and min limits that we use now, we can use the hinge joint even for implementing `ODEFixedJoint`.

## Bullet 
I used `btGeneric6DofSpringConstraint` with all limits set to 0, mainly because there is a comment in bullet source code that mentions problems with the `btFixedConstraint` [1]. I don't know if this problems are fixed in `btGeneric6DofSpringConstraint` or just in `btGeneric6DofSpring2Constraint`, but adding support for `btGeneric6DofSpring2Constraint` if we use Bullet 2.83 will be trivial. 

Currently the `BulletFixedJoint::GetForceTorque` function is returning `NaN`, so the branch is still not ready for opening a PR, but for anyone interested is already available at https://bitbucket.org/traversaro/gazebo-fork/branch/issue_1278 .

[1] : https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/blob/master/examples/Importers/ImportURDFDemo/URDF2Bullet.cpp#L304
content.html:
I had some time to spent on this and I decided to go on and implement the fixed joint support also on the other physics engine, because the amount of physics engine-specific code necessary was surprisingly limited.

Simbody

Simbody implementation seems to work fine, using SimTK::MobilizedBody::Weld.

DART

DART was implemented using dart::dynamics::WeldJoint and it seems to work fine.

ODE

ODE was implemented using the Fixed joint. If for any reason this fixed joint is more unstable than the Hinge joint with 0 max and min limits that we use now, we can use the hinge joint even for implementing ODEFixedJoint.

Bullet

I used btGeneric6DofSpringConstraint with all limits set to 0, mainly because there is a comment in bullet source code that mentions problems with the btFixedConstraint [1]. I don't know if this problems are fixed in btGeneric6DofSpringConstraint or just in btGeneric6DofSpring2Constraint, but adding support for btGeneric6DofSpring2Constraint if we use Bullet 2.83 will be trivial.

Currently the BulletFixedJoint::GetForceTorque function is returning NaN, so the branch is still not ready for opening a PR, but for anyone interested is already available at https://bitbucket.org/traversaro/gazebo-fork/branch/issue_1278 .

[1] : https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/blob/master/examples/Importers/ImportURDFDemo/URDF2Bullet.cpp#L304

issue.title: support fixed joint types in Gazebo

content.raw:
Update: Trying to get `btGeneric6DofSpringConstraint` to get a valid `GetForceTorque` result turned out to be problematic. 
There was a sign mismatch with respect to the result obtained by using a `btHingeConstraint`, and also other problems with the torque values. Hence in [1] I switched to use a simple `btHingeConstraint` with max and min limits set to 0.0, given that the `revolute` joint `GetForceTorque` more and less works. 

After this modification, the test that I pushed for `GetForceTorque` on fixed joints is working on all the four physics engine, and it also exposed some problems in `prismatic` joints for simbody and bullet, reported in #1639 and #1640 .

[1] : https://bitbucket.org/traversaro/gazebo-fork/commits/40e922207574aeab9ba4ba3fa159f33b08891a90
content.html:
Update: Trying to get btGeneric6DofSpringConstraint to get a valid GetForceTorque result turned out to be problematic. There was a sign mismatch with respect to the result obtained by using a btHingeConstraint, and also other problems with the torque values. Hence in [1] I switched to use a simple btHingeConstraint with max and min limits set to 0.0, given that the revolute joint GetForceTorque more and less works.

After this modification, the test that I pushed for GetForceTorque on fixed joints is working on all the four physics engine, and it also exposed some problems in prismatic joints for simbody and bullet, reported in #1639 and #1640 .

[1] : https://bitbucket.org/traversaro/gazebo-fork/commits/40e922207574aeab9ba4ba3fa159f33b08891a90

PR created both in SDFormat ( https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/194/support-for-fixed-joints/diff#comment-None ) and Gazebo ( #!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1747 ).

 I will be more than happy to address any concern .
